ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3 hr
3-5 hours
5 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths: thought an important often overlooked topic. Had great guest speakers.Weakness: could have been better organized.

The course was poorly organized and it was difficult to get in touch with the professor outside of the classroom. The assignments were not clearly specified at the beginning of the semester and the weekly homework was sometimes posted extremely late in the week. The lectures were average and loosely tied in with the readings. The course would benefit from more consistent feedback; it was unclear whether we received credit for our homework assignments.
The guest speakers were a real highlight in this course, they had a diversity of experience in industry.
We could learn a lot from this course.
This was a great course, it was exactly what I had expected and wanted to learn.I wouldn't change anything about this course, you get exactly what you expect.
strength: guest lectures are interesting;weakness: too many lecture slides per one class

The course combination of core lectures and external speakers is phenomenal. Many classes could benefit from this arrangement as one directly observes the relevance of the taught concepts. Great!At times, the curriculum could be a bit better structured. For example, when revising for the final exam it still felt tough to elicit the underlying logic of lecture sequence, interdependence between topics etc.The homework assignments felt dull at times. Mostly, they involved citing the course text book. A 20% presentation on a regulatory affairs strategy for an hypothetical drug in development could be more exciting.
excellent.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Robert Makuch  Strengths- flexible, open to feedback and meeting with students. Made class interesting with real world examples.Weakness - needs to check Yale email much more often.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Makuch was great and truly helpful!

Instructor: Robert Makuch  The instructor did not seem interested in teaching and was not easily accessible to students outside of the classroom. The instructor did not attend class when there were guest lecturers; I've had guest lecturers in several classes at YSPH and I've never seen a professor skip those sessions.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dedicated professor, really cares about the class and the subject.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  He is really knowledgable and has a large resource

Instructor: Robert Makuch  Dr. Makuch is great. He knows the material, he is engaging and always available to sit down and talk. He has great insight into the regulatory affairs process and it is enjoyable to hear about his experiences and perspectives.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  Strength: has practical knowldge and connections with FDA; helpful in job searchweakness: very very interested in whether students have learned

Instructor: Robert Makuch  The instructor is extremely knowledgeable and enriches class delivery with real examples. Great!For some lectures, one might consider leveraging the TA role for delivering some of the more basic regulatry concepts more tactically.
Instructor: Robert Makuch  excellent. very enthusiastic for the topics and concepts tought.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Anita was great.
TA had never taken this course so while we learned, she was also learning. She was helpful but it would have been nice to have a TA that previously took this course.
The TA was helpful.
Anita Sung - great TA, knowledgeable and helpful.
Anita is helpful
The TA was a great resource.
strength: responsible in handling homework, examsweakness: N/A
Can't comment due to limited interactions.
The TA was very helpful.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Great course, great guest lecturers, could be organized a bit better.
If you are in the regulatory affairs track, and are planning to take both BIS 575 and BIS 561, you may expect synergistic effects:)

The course is somewhat useful. Be prepared to teach yourself the concepts that are most important to you. I would not recommend the course to someone who is looking to get a lot out of his or her classes.
I would highly recommend taking this course it will give you a good overview on how the FDA really works.
Belive or not, this course is very practical in real world, if you are interested in pharma industry.
Great course, I would recommend it for anyone interested in going into reg. affairs after graduation.
a good introductory course to regulatory affairs if you are interested
Very good introductory class to FDA regulations on drugs.Professor is very knowledgable and workload is below average.
Great course! Would recommend it to a fellow student.
excellent. recommendable to all MPH students.
